It is not fair to the farmers who control the largest industry in the country to be kept in the suspense which they are in for the last twelve months.

In Northern Ireland de-rating is in operation, and it is very hard for our farmers to compete in the English markets with the Northern farmer who has de-rating already. It ought not be necessary for me or for any Deputy to point out that obvious fact to the Minister for Finance. I do hope that the Minister for Finance will say something about these important matters, that is, coast erosion and de-rating, and that he will not content himself with telling us that Commissions have been set up to inquire into these two matters. I say that because people have come to look upon these Commissions merely as eye-wash.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Brodrick Mr. J. Brodrick
Speaker.P: I think the question was asked recently by Deputy Lemass as to why Irish slates were not used by housing authorities, and I observed that the Minister's answer was that Irish slates would mean an increase per house in the building costs of about £8. Leaving that aside, one would imagine that in the matter of the buildings that they have erected throughout the country the Government were not interested in Irish materials being put into the buildings. That is what one would gather from some of the statements made here. But that is not the case. Anyone who takes up a specification of the Board of Works will find that it is not so. In the last few years hundreds of thousands of pounds have been expended under the supervision of the Board of Works, and in all their specifications they ask for Irish slates and for Irish materials. In these buildings practically every article of Irish material that can be used is specified for by the Board of Works. Take that and compare it with what the local authorities are doing in this matter of Irish material. The local authorities spend a large amount of money on buildings. I would like anyone to notice the contrast between the specifications of the local authorities and the specifications of the Board of Works. If one will compare the interest that is taken by the local authorities in the provision of Irish manufactured material in the building of houses with the interest taken by the Government, one will see that there is a very big difference. One will find that in the specifications of the Board of Works everything possible is done by the Government for the relief of unemployment.

MainHeading.P: I do not see therefore that any charge can be made against the Government in this matter. I know for my own part that in the specifications I have seen, so far as the use of Irish material is concerned, everything is done to see that Irish material is used. Now as to local authorities, we must remember this, that on the question of housing we find that Irish slates will cost £8 per house more than artificial imported slates. We all agree that at present building costs are rather high and one must remember that even £8 in the building of a house is a big thing. I would like to know from the Minister for Local Government and Public Health when he speaks of this difference of £8 per house if that difference really comes in as between the Irish slates and the artificial slates or whether some of it is made up in the difference in the cost of the timber portion of the roof. I expect that when roofing with asbestos slate, the woodwork of the roof will be cheaper than the woodwork required where Irish slates are put on. Then there is another matter we will have to consider and that is the life of the artificial slate as against the length of life of the Irish slate. I would like to know if the Minister for Local Government and Public Health could tell us approximately the life period of both slates. If we find that there is a big difference in the life-time of the Irish slate, that it lasts longer than the other slates, then the matter of £8 per house is a very small matter. If you take a house that costs from £300 to £500, a difference of £8 in the cost of slate is a very small matter indeed. For myself I would like that in all their building schemes local authorities would act in the same way in the matter of Irish material as the Government has been acting through the Board of Works and see that wherever they are putting up a house they will specify Irish materials.

Speaker.P: Before I deal with what was perhaps the main subject of the discussion this evening I just want to mention one or two matters that were raised. I was asked about the issuing of a national loan and when the remaining part of the Second National Loan would be issued. Decisions have not yet been definitely come to as to the conditions under which that loan will be issued or the exact date of the loan. Deputies will be aware that the fall in the bank rate that has taken place recently makes the position more favourable. Unless there was to be a change in the opposite direction, there would certainly be no justification for the postponement of the issue of the second part of the National Loan beyond the present year.

Our position has been that if the conditions of the money market were unfavourable we would not issue even in the present year the second part of the loan, though the amount of the floating debt has now become so large that it would be inconvenient to carry on. In spite, however of that inconvenience, we would carry on for a further period if it were necessary. It is clear now that there will be no necessity for postponing the issuing of the loan beyond the present year. The exact amount to be asked for in the future issue is a matter that will be determined a week or two before the issue is made, because it will all depend on the precise conditions of the money market at the time the issue is made.

With regard to the matter of de-rating, about which Deputy Corry asked a question, whatever may be the findings or recommendations of the De-rating Commission and no matter whether their report be issued next month or whether it is issued at the end of six months from now, it may be taken that there will be no assistance beyond the amount already provided from the Central Exchequer towards the relief of rates on the farmers in the financial year that begins on the 1st April. Even if we had their recommendations next month and were able to make proposals in the forthcoming Budget to enable de-rating to be carried out, it would not be possible to carry it out so as to give effect to it during the year which begins on the first of next month. I think that is all the reply I can give to Deputy Corry on that question.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the re-summoning of the Banking Commission, no consideration has yet been given to that, and I am not sure that even if we were re-summoning it in pursuance of the suggestion to which Deputy Lemass referred, it could be satisfactorily done within so early a period as five years from the date of the last sitting, because there were certain delays in drafting the Bill which became the Currency Act after the Bill had been passed. There were certain delays even connected with the passage of the Bill, and after the Bill had passed there were delays in putting the Act into operation. The delays were not very long, but still they were appreciable. I now refer to the putting of the Act into full operation. The result will be, for instance, that the first reallocation of bank note issue, which would be one of the important functions of the Currency Commission, will not be due to take place for something like one and a half years.

Questions were asked about the Road Fund. I think that Deputies should ask for the information they require by way of Parliamentary Questions to the Minister for Local Government. He does not happen to be available at the moment. If they are not satisfied with the answers he gives it would be possible to have the matter raised on the adjournment. It is doubtful if anything relating to the Road Fund arises in a definite way on this particular Bill. There is no money being provided for the Road Fund here. Of course, there is money being provided for the salary of the Minister for Local Government, and perhaps then it could be raised; but it does not arise very clearly out of this Central Fund Bill.

I was glad that Deputy Lemass made the statement he did make with regard to the Wigg and Cochrane case, but I do not believe it will produce any beneficial results. I do not think that the people who make allegations of uncertainty really believe that Fianna Fáil is going to return to power at the next election. I think that they are ready to make any wild statement in support of their application, and hence the appearance of believing that there is going to be a Fianna Fáil Government soon.

The main questions that arose in this discussion were the burden of taxation and the problem of unemployment. I think that Deputy MacEntee and certain other speakers in different parts of their speeches, and Deputy Lemass in the main part of his speech, were at variance. They were arguing for totally different things. Deputy MacEntee's speech, and parts of the speeches of other Deputies, were a call for less expenditure, for a lightening of the burdens on agriculture and industry. A good deal of the speech of Deputy Lemass, in fact the main part of it, was a call for increased burdens. Speeches of other Deputies were composed more or less of definite demands for increased expenditure, and hence increased burdens on agriculture and industry. I know that whether industry can or cannot bear a particular burden does depend to a very large extent on the objects upon which expenditure takes place. Nevertheless, any expenditure whatever does tend to make the task of those who are carrying on industry and agriculture somewhat more difficult.

I must confess I do not take the demands which are made from the other side of the House for a lessening of the burdens on industry and agriculture, and for a policy aiming at a remission of taxation, very seriously. I think the main policy of Fianna Fáil, and perhaps of other groups—perhaps the main attitude of the majority of Deputies in the House—is to ask for more expenditure. Some Deputies want additional expenditure for one object; other Deputies want it for another object. In this debate, as in nearly all debates, even debates on the Estimates, suggestions are made that the State should undertake new activities, that they should do things they are not doing, or that they should increase their activity and expenditure on things that are already done. All that simply amounts to a demand that fresh expenditure should be incurred, with the inevitable consequence of fresh taxation. Suggestions that all sorts of new expenditure, whether on social services, education, or whatever desirable object they are to be incurred in connection with—different forms of fresh expenditure—can be incurred without increasing the burden of taxation are really altogether nonsensical. When we come to discuss Estimates Deputies will have an opportunity, if they are able, of trying to point out to the House where economies could be effected, where savings could be made that would enable new types of expenditure to be undertaken without asking anything more from the taxpayer.

I believe that any Deputy who will be quite frank about the matter will confess, after detailed examination of the Estimates, that very small sums can be obtained in comparison with the sums that are being demanded by anything in the nature of economies on existing services. In the end it will be found that if Deputies want to undertake new services they must be prepared to suppress existing services. If we leave out one or two things which are mainly interesting because of their political character, and which are of relatively little importance financially, there is practically no demand in the House, and there has not at any time been a demand, for the suppression of services. The sort of thing certain Deputies will say is that the expenditure on the Governor-General's establishment should be wiped out, and one or two other things like that which would not provide money for financing large schemes of any sort. Beyond that all existing services will find supporters in the House and will find a majority of the members supporting them and, in a great many cases, even asking for an increase in connection with them.

We have to face the fact that if the State is to do more in any direction, it is going to mean more taxation. If we are going to do more towards the solution of the unemployment problem it will mean more taxation, with whatever consequences may follow from that taxation. If we are going to give incentives to people to establish industries, that means more taxation and increased burdens on the people as a consequence of the increased taxation. The same thing applies to education and every other service. It even applies to Bills which may have been introduced and that do not directly involve any great expenditure. Even a Bill that does not seem to involve expenditure very often does result in increased charges falling on the Exchequer and on the people, because when it becomes law it has to be put into force, and whether it is a civic guard or another official who has to enforce it, the cost of enforcement is something and adds to the burden. The time required in the enforcement of a particular Act may be the deciding factor as to whether in a particular section in an office another clerk is required or as to whether in a particular barrack or a particular police sub-district an additional civic guard is required.

On the Order Paper at the moment there are three notices of Bills to be introduced by Fianna Fáil Deputies which would all tend to increase expenditure, if passed. The Old Age Pensions Bill would involve a very great increase in expenditure, perhaps more than £300,000 per annum. The first of the notices of motion, No. 23, if passed, would presumably involve some annual expenditure, and, if the House were to pass No. 25 I think one way and another it would result in a considerable waste. There would be a considerable expenditure of public money on a most futile project.

Speaker.P: Would the Minister state the revenue from No. 26?

Revenue is a charge on the people. It might be very refreshing to the Minister for Finance simply from the point of view of the Budget to have a motion like that passed, but it does not really affect the point I am putting before the Dáil now. That would bring revenue in, but it would involve expenditure on the collection of revenue, even if it brought it in. Deputy Lemass then urged that drastic steps should be taken to deal with the problem of unemployment. He urged that it was not merely the duty of the Government, but the wisest policy of the Government, as representing the people of the State, to adopt great schemes for the immediate solution of the problem of unemployment.

Now the consideration of the question of unemployment, I quite freely admit, is not the monopoly of any party of this House. Deputy Lemass suggested, perhaps more jocularly than otherwise, that representatives of Cumann na nGaedheal had not considered it. Of course they have considered it, and were bound to consider it as members of the Government were bound to consider it. I do not retort by saying that representatives of the Fianna Fáil Party had not considered it. It is a thing none of us can ignore. It is a thing heartrending instances of which are brought before all of us from time to time, and a great deal more frequently than could happen without a person feeling the matter to be very serious indeed. There is the question of whether or not this problem can be solved by Government action or whether it must be solved, indirectly, in so far as the Government contributes to its solution, by inducing, encouraging or helping private employers to give employment or simply by leaving the way open for private employers to give employment. I personally do not believe that it can be solved by any Government action which it would be possible to take in a democratically organised State with parliamentary government.

MainHeading.P: Great experiments are being carried on in other countries at present. Some of the results of those experiments are terrible results, but I do not know what knowledge or what useful methods will ultimately be evolved as a result of those experiments. It may be that things will come out of these experiments which will be of benefit to all countries—knowledge, information and technique in regard to industry. These things may come out of these experiments in State control of industry which are being carried on, one of them being an experiment of a more drastic and radical type than another, but I do say if the State sets out to solve the unemployment problem it must be prepared to go a great deal further than I think there is any possibility of the people of this country being prepared to go.

Our form of State machinery was really organised, I suppose, primarily to maintain order, to keep a system of law courts, generally to carry on police work, and to give protection from international attack. From that we have passed on to the carrying on of a good number of important and valuable social services. Nevertheless our whole system is really built up on the supposition that you have private enterprise, the freedom of the private individual in carrying on his industry, dependent on his intelligence, his interest in the work and his general capacity. If the State is going to deal in a radical way with the question of unemployment it involves, I think, more perhaps than Deputy Lemass has contemplated. His suggestion, that we can deal with unemployment even temporarily, while promoting public utility schemes on a large scale, I do not think will bear examination.

For instance, there are very large numbers of our unemployed who could not possibly be put to work on public utility schemes no matter how extensive the public utility schemes we were carrying out might be. You cannot put to work, say, a woman of delicate physique digging trenches for one of those sewerage and water schemes. There are large numbers of men unemployed you could not possibly put to work on anything in connection with public utility schemes. If we are to carry out public utility schemes on a very large scale we are up against this difficulty that you cannot borrow all that money unless you can see that the expenditure will come to an end in a very short time. The only part of the money you would be justified, strictly speaking, in borrowing would be the part the local authority would repay. If the local authority is not going to repay any of it—and Deputy Lemass went so far as to suggest that we should finance these works wholly out of the Exchequer —then we would be justified in borrowing very little of it unless we can clearly foresee that neither that expenditure nor any expenditure replacing it was going to be continued beyond two or three years.

If we were going to take the point of view that it was going to continue, and would have to continue—I think that was the only reasonable point of view—for a considerable time, then we would have to raise large sums by additional taxation. These large sums will have the effect of reducing employment somewhere else. If a great increase of £5,000,000 of taxation were to be added, many people who are able to carry on and give employment would cease to be able to give employment, and in consequence, even if we were able, by some comprehensive scheme of public work, to employ all those at present unemployed, the immediate consequence would be that new unemployed would come in to take their place. It would require very little pressure on industry and agriculture in the way of additional taxation to squeeze a new 50,000 people out of employment, if we were to take 50,000 as the number. There are certainly, very distinctly, two sides to the whole story. With regard to the great scheme of housing which would solve the housing problem in a few years, which Deputy Lemass suggests, I think that practically none of the results that he foreshadows could be obtained. First, it is very difficult for a Government Department to carry on a scheme which involves business transactions on a large scale and the employment of great numbers of people.

Speaker.P: The Shannon Board.

You might get over some of the difficulties by having a Board, for the individual acts of which the Minister would not be responsible. Of course it would be impossible for any Board who would have to answer say to the Comptroller and Auditor-General and comply with the strict tests which he would require, to carry on business transactions. You might by putting it outside the ordinary range of Government departments, as in the case of the Shannon Board, remove a number of the difficulties, but you cannot by any means remove them all. A thing like a great Housing Board would result in so much political pressure that I doubt whether it would be possible for a Minister to say “I have no responsibility for that, it is the Board's job, and they must be left to do it.” I think that, as a matter of fact, it would be impossible to prevent issuing from the Dáil directions of one sort or another, it would be impossible to prevent the passing of resolutions by the Dáil that houses should be let at this particular rent, or should be built of this particular type, or in this particular place, or that the strike which had taken place should be settled on some particular terms. I believe it would be very difficult. Once that sort of thing began you would have the agitation of the large number of people employed for favoured conditions, conditions better than they would have in outside employment, higher wages, shorter hours and all that. Undoubtedly, a large number of people in State employment would agitate for that and would employ all the political pressure they could muster in order to obtain it, and differences of that sort would arise. I believe again that the carrying out of housing at a very much more rapid rate than it has heretofore been done would run up the cost. There would be apparent at once a labour shortage and the consequence of the labour shortage would be what they call labour troubles. Even if the State were acting as contractor there would be great difficulty in organising a new thing like that. A thing I must say which has a great deal of effect in my mind in connection with these things was the difficulty even of organising—of course it was under civil war conditions—such a simple thing as an army which, after all, is a very simple thing to organise, the tremendous difficulties of getting anything like discipline, efficiency, economy and order.

MainHeading.P: I believe the organisation of a big scheme for carrying on a thing like housing would be very great. If it were built up slowly one could get efficiency as one went along, but if there were any attempt to create a great organisation suddenly I believe you would have innumerable misfits, you would have all sorts of problems imperfectly understood, and there would inevitably be great blunders, great waste and a great deal of general inefficiency. If the Board carried itself beyond the erection of houses in the cheapest way possible to the provision of slates, bricks, cement, paint, glass, pipes, and so on, then we would have a whole series of technical and difficult processes of manufacture to supervise. If the Board were not to carry out these manufactures itself and had to get other people to do it, it would be subject, in its anxiety to get on in the peculiar situation, to a great deal of pressure, a great deal of something that would correspond to profiteering. Apart from the mere question of profiteering, if you are going to set up a new industry specifically to supply the needs of a particular corporation, you are going to have very high costs; you are going to pay for all the cost of the training of a staff, the initial mistakes, and everything that handicaps an industry at the start. I think the inevitable consequence of trying to do housing on the very large scale that Deputy Lemass suggests and by the means Deputy Lemass suggests would be perhaps that you would get more houses, but that you would get them on the whole at a very much dearer rate. If you went out to get materials specially made and all that sort of thing, it would mean anything up to 50 per cent. more than the houses are costing at the present time. I believe that a board like that, even if it confined itself simply to ordering in bulk and to setting up a staff to supervise the erection of houses, could effect very few economies. I doubt very much whether any economies at all could be effected.

Speaker.P: Will the Minister undertake to examine the operation of that Vienna scheme as reported in the “Star”?

Every country has its own conditions. A particular action of the State or of the State authority in a country will produce its own reactions. In one place where people perhaps have passed through starvation and the most harrowing times, you will be able to get from all classes a co-operation that you would not get in a country where, although great numbers of people are very poor, the whole population has not passed through the difficulties and the hardships that they have experienced in other countries.

I am not saying for a moment that in any sphere of Government activity the last word has been said or that absolutely everything possible has been done. I am not really talking now about the possibility of speeding up housing, because that is a matter that will come on in other debates and can be discussed at length. I am really discussing the possibility of doing housing in such a way as to contribute substantially towards the relief of unemployment. Deputy Lemass suggested that by a housing scheme and by the carrying out of public utility works like water and sewerage schemes it would be possible to provide for all those who are at present unemployed. I do not want to hold him to that phrase, because I think he left out of account the fact that large numbers of the unemployed are women and large numbers are men who would not be physically fit to take part in work of that kind.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy proceeded to suggest that, apart from these things which were rather in the nature of temporary expedients, the unemployment problem could be met by wholesale tariffs. He said that there are nine and a half million pounds worth of tariffed goods being imported and seven and a half million pounds worth which, although not tariffed, were goods which could be produced here and presumably could be made the subject of protective tariffs. I think there is not a shadow of a chance that if you put on the highest possible tariff the number of people that Deputy Lemass suggests will be absorbed in industry. The stoppage of the import of some articles which are of a fairly high value would not give very much employment. He mentioned flour, which is a case in point. It is admitted that although flour imports bulk largely and account for a large sum of money, if the import of flour were stopped by the imposition of a tariff very little extra employment would result. As a matter of fact, it is even arguable, although some people at present employed might be put on whole time, whether additional persons would be employed as a result of the stoppage of the import of flour, because larger units would be created, units where a less amount of employment would be given per thonsand sacks, or per any other quantity.

Speaker.P: What about subsidiary industries?
The same thing applies both to tariffs and subsidies.
I said subsidiary industries.

When it is said that 13,000 people had been given employment as a result of the tariffs already imposed, there is no doubt that other people have got employment in subsidiary industries or businesses. If you have a large number of people employed in a particular industry in a town where there was no industry before, you are going to have grocers and bootmakers, and even bookmakers, employed consequentially, and the 13,000 persons, I do not think, represent by any means the full number of those in employment who would not be employed if tariffs had not been imposed. I do not want to get involved in a tariff debate, but I think I should state my view again, that any group of tariffs do result in an increase of cost to the consumer. You can find individual tariffs that may not result in an increased cost. There are individual tariffs in operation here which have not resulted in any additional cost to the consumer, whether we reckon the cost in a higher price or in an inferior quality supplied. There are tariffs which have resulted in no extra cost to the consumer, but other tariffs have.

MainHeading.P: I think somebody mentioned boots. It is very difficult to show in individual cases whether an extra cost has fallen on the consumer or not, and, if an extra cost has fallen on the consumer, what it amounts to. I mentioned a long time ago in this House that home boot manufacturers were with very great difficulty able to compete with outside boot manufacturers. I mentioned that in many cases where contracts for army boots were being given they had to be given to outside firms, because, even when fifteen per cent. had been added to the price of the outside firms, it was still substantially lower than the lowest tender put in by any Irish manufacturer. Only the other week I saw a list of prices submitted by firms tendering for the supply of army boots and boots for Post Office messengers, and I saw that several English firms, in the case of one of these contracts, quoted at prices which, even when fifteen per cent. had been added, were substantially lower than the lowest price which an Irish firm had put in, not a mere sixpence or anything like that, but substantially lower. When one sees that happening again and again, it is impossible to resist the conclusion that the tariff, say, in the matter of boots, is actually resulting in an increase to the consumer. So far as the foreign boots are concerned, of course, that increase does not matter, because anything extra that the consumer is paying in respect of foreign boots will go into the Exchequer and is serving to prevent some other tax being put on, just as when the boot tax was first introduced the revenue which was obtained from that tax enabled the tax on tea to be taken off. But so far as Irish boots are concerned, the position seems to be that the consumer is paying about the fifteen per cent. more than he would otherwise pay, and the Exchequer is getting nothing out of it. There is there a direct subsidy which is being paid by the general consumer to keep the boot factories in operation.

Speaker.P: I should like to ask the Minister what price was quoted for boots for the Army or the Post Office?

I am not going to tell the price. I would not mind letting any Deputy privately see the price of a contract which had been given, say, two or three years ago, which would not affect tendering in future, but I would not like to show the last price.
Would the Minister mind if I told him the price quoted for boots for the Army in the past?
I think the Deputy will have to let me continue.
I am sure the Minister would rather I did.

The position, as I say, as far as it can be judged, is, that an actual subsidy is being paid, and I believe will for long continue to be paid, by the consumer to the home boot manufacturer. If the boot manufacturing industry really establishes itself here, as I hope it will, a point will be reached when the boot factories will be able to carry on, and there will be sufficient competition amongst themselves to enable them to hold the trade of the country and to reduce their prices to something like the outside level. If and when that takes place, we will have a considerable body of employment given throughout the country at no cost to the consumer. Meantime what is actually happening is that for the development of that industry the public at large is being taxed. I believe that while there are exceptions, and perhaps we can point to exceptions already, and while if a general scheme of tariffs were adopted, more exceptions would be seen, the general result would be that the actual cost to the consumer would be increased. That is that the amount which the consumer would pay would be substantially greater than anything that would come into the revenue; the additional amount he would pay for the goods would be substantially greater than the amount coming in to the revenue and the taxpayer would be compelled to pay to these various industries a subsidy for as long as they were unable really to compete with outside firms in order to help them to develop.

MainHeading.P: If we put on a general tariff, as suggested by Deputy Lemass, we would get a substantial amount of additional employment in industry. If the tariffs were high enough we would get that increase fairly rapidly. If the tariffs were moderate it would be slow. But if the tariffs are very high and almost prohibitive in their nature we would get that increase very rapidly but subject to a certain handicap. If we put 100 per cent. on boots instead of 15 per cent. the immediate result would be that firms would rush in, and companies would be established, which would buy up existing buildings anywhere and would put in machinery, almost regardless of cost, anxious to get into the market and get a share of the profit while the going was good. We would have factories very badly laid out, over-capitalised, and all sorts of commitments entered into which would burden the industry for all time. If we put on such a tax as 100 per cent. we could within a few years have seven or eight thousand people employed in the boot industry, but we would have done something that would mean that the price of boots would remain, for as long as the tariff lasted, higher than the price of boots in England or the price here if there were free imports. We would have that industry getting a permanent subsidy from other industries in the country. If we similarly put a tariff on other industries each of these would impose some burden on the boot industry, and make it difficult for it to carry on. Besides, if we had 75 or 100 per cent. increase in the price of boots it would undoubtedly be a very substantial burden on other people and would make it difficult for them to carry on. It would mean that capital helping to enable a small firm to be carried on would be eaten up by this additional and great increase in the cost of living.

I believe, again, if we went in for this policy of wholesale tariffs with a view to a rapid solution of the unemployment problem we could not solve that problem. It is quite possible that the result of that particular thing would be greater unemployment in the country rather than less, because of the fact that people would be squeezed out of agriculture and out of any odd industry, if any were left, which was not tariffed, and we would be in the same position as before with this permanent burden of overhead charges arising from the uneconomic methods of starting industries. I believe if good results are to be got from tariffs we should not look for too speedy results. We should not put on tariffs more than will enable an industry to get established if everything is done in the most economical way possible. Industry can only carry on if every care is taken to establish factories on reasonable sites, to give them a proper lay out, and to avoid burdening them with unnecessary initial charges. I believe these are the methods whereby industries can be increased.

I do not believe it is possible by tariffs to get a speedy remedy for unemployment. I believe that while the State may do many things—and the State has done a great many things to help industry and give employment—the main work can only be done by private firms, individual business men or groups of business men developing manufacturing industries here. I believe if the State could find fully reproductive expenditure the State should enter into it. The State should have a look out for schemes such as the Shannon scheme or any other scheme which seems reasonably certain will repay what is laid out upon them. If this State could devise or find any such scheme it ought unhesitatingly to enter upon it. I think it is reasonable for the State to do a certain amount of work which is not fully reproductive in order to give some relief when unemployment is exceptionally acute or when there is any special circumstance that aggravates the evil. But I do not think we could solve it by carrying out public works on a great scale or at great expenditure or by any scheme such as wholesale protection. I think a certain alleviation could be effected but what we have got to do, in the main, is to promote and assist and encourage private enterprise to develop and to extend industries which are already in existence and to find new industries.

Deputy MacEntee, I think, asked for a reduction in expenditure and for the owner of private business to be assisted. When Deputy Lemass is asking for great schemes to be carried out by the Government he is almost asking for a disregard of the persons conducting private business and suggesting that the whole thing should be taken on the shoulders of the State. If we really decided to take the main burden upon the shoulders of the State I think we must assume it should be taken almost entirely upon the shoulders of the State because if we are having great increases in taxation and great schemes of new works then there will be no hope that very much will be done by individual firms.

We would be raising new difficulties before them every day. On the other hand, I do not think it is practically possible to say that it is all a matter for the private business man. I have heard people put up very extreme views in that respect. I have heard people say that all sorts of common services should be abandoned, or almost abandoned. I have heard people suggest that the whole of the Insurance Acts should be repealed. I do not think that that is practicable. I do not think that it is possible to abandon these social services. I have heard people urge that except primary education all other sorts of education should be left to private individuals. I do not think that that is practicable either. I do not think that it is going to give good results. Consequently, I think that there is no policy that could be more effective than the policy that has been pursued up to the present, a policy of carrying out schemes like the Shannon scheme, which we calculate to be fully remunerative, schemes like afforestation, arterial drainage, and small drainage schemes, which are reckoned to be partially reproductive, encouraging housing, partly to give employment and partly to improve the health of the people, and for other social reasons—doing these things concurrently with the giving of protection to industries, after the best type of investigation that could be carried out, the provision of facilities, for what they are worth, under the Trade Loans Act and other measures of the same kind. I cannot see that simply putting down our heads and taking some course, irrespective of the consequences of pursuing that course, numerous indirect consequences, will help us at all.

I think that if what is being done in regard to unemployment is to be improved it is to be improved, not by adopting some entirely different method, but by bettering the details of the method which we have already adopted, by thinking out new reproductive schemes, by trying to get local authorities and others to do more on their side in connection with the housing problem, by generally tightening up details bringing other elements in the community, both local authorities and private individuals, in to help, and making them conscious of their duty in the matter. I do not, however, think that it is possible to find any royal road towards the solution of the grave problem of unemployment. That problem is rampant in many countries and in countries where we do not find it we find conditions in many respects radically different from our conditions. In some countries where there is less unemployment the extra work is secured at the price of very much poorer standards of pay and much poorer standards on the part of the workers. In some countries, unemployment is, at any rate, partially solved in that way. I do not think that we can very rapidly get rid of this terrible evil. I think that one of the reasons for unemployment here, although perhaps very often we see a manifestation of the evil more clearly in towns, lies in the effect of the depressed conditions in England on our agriculture. I do not know how we are to avoid suffering for a long time from the effects of the depressed conditions in England. This country is mainly agricultural. It is not an economically well-balanced country and remedies that may be immediately available in countries well-balanced economically, countries with industries substantially developed, would not be effective in a country which had not yet reached that stage. If we had big industries here we could do things for agriculture which we cannot do now, because, if we do them now, we would be taking the money out of one pocket of the agriculturist and putting it into another pocket. We are dependent on agriculture and we can only solve our problems by improvising industry. Industry, if it is to be a source of wealth, rather than a burden, must grow and must have the time it requires to grow on sound lines.

Speaker.P: Would the Minister say whether there is any possibility of money from the Local Loans Fund being advanced for housing at a lower rate of interest in the near future in view of the fact that the bank rate has been reduced by one and a half or two per cent. since the annuity was fixed?

I do not think that there is any possibility of that. The annuity was fixed not with a view to the prevailing money rates, but with a view to the rates of interest at which the Government has to borrow. I think, having regard to the conditions under which we must borrow, to the price at which the loan is issued, to the cost of issue, including advertising and anything else that may fall to be met, the repayments of the loan, the interest and other burdens which fall on the Exchequer, also the fact that the loan to the local authority will be given over a longer period than that for which the Government has borrowed, and that the Exchequer will have to meet the difference in the rates of repayment—there may be a fractional difference but I do not think that any less rate would be what I may call a business rate.
Might I also ask if there is money available in the Fund for water works and sewerage schemes?
Yes.

Might I ask the Minister whether in pursuing the policy which he mentions, of assisting and encouraging Irish industries, he has ever considered the advisability of carrying out a national drive to persuade the Irish people to buy Irish goods, or of devoting a sum of, say, £10,000 for carrying out a drive of that kind by advertising or otherwise?

There is a great difference of opinion about that. I have not much belief in its efficacy, but I think the President has some belief in its efficacy. While you might get some people to buy Irish goods by action of that kind, there is just a possibility that you would convince other people that Irish goods were not up to the mark. A boot manufacturer told me that when, in certain shops which he controls, he marked boots with the name of the firm, he could not sell them, but when he marked them A. B. and Co. he sold them all right, because they were not known as Irish goods. I do not profess to say what the effect of such propaganda would be, but I have been told that while the campaign which was carried on for years in favour of Irish goods had the result of making a certain number of people go to great trouble and even expense in order to secure Irish goods, it had on other people the effect of making them feel that there was something fishy about Irish goods.
I asked the Minister one question already which he could not answer. I will ask him another now.
I am not going to answer any question from Deputy Carney.

There is just one question. How can the Minister reconcile his attitude in regard to the question of supplying boots to the Free State Army with the attitude he took up when I was Chief Supplies Officer to what is now called the National Army? When they were offered 50,000 pairs of boots, cast American Army boots, at 5/- a pair, they would not take them because they were not of Irish manufacture. Now the Minister tells me that they are taking foreign boots because they are cheaper than the boots made by Irishmen.

I want to know from the Minister how a tariff on the importation of foreign bacon, butter, milk, eggs, malt and barley would injure the farmer. I would also like to know when we are going to have the result of the De-Rating Commission.
I answered that when the Deputy was out.
Will the Minister say whether the £600,000 which is due to be lodged to the Road Fund is to be repaid this year?

I do not think it needs to be, but then I suggest to the Deputy that he should put down a question on the various points in connection with the Road Fund on which he wants information. I think it hardly arises in this debate, and the Minister for Local Government is not here. I do not think that it was arranged that the sum would be paid in any one year. I believe from recollection that there was a period of years laid down. I think the Deputy should put down a question in regard to the matter. In regard to the question which Deputy Corry raised, for instance about Irish bacon, although I did not discuss it at great length, I believe it has been discussed at great length in the Dáil. The real point of the matter is that a tariff on American bacon would do the farmer no good, and it perhaps would deprive large numbers of people of the sort of bacon they want. If the sort of bacon they want were to be supplied from home factories it would introduce certain complications, because I understand that home factories have really complained that Irish farmers, or at least a certain number of them, do not produce pigs exactly of the weight and in the condition in which they want them. If you are to have a farmer taking out his pigs in the condition and at the right size for the bacon factories for the existing trade, and producing other pigs for home use, you are probably not going to help the export trade, and there is any amount of trade to be done in the export of bacon.
What about the case of milk, eggs and other things which I mentioned?
I took one example.

The Minister said that amongst the various ways of lessening unemployment, one would be bettering the details of the methods we have already adopted. I would like to know what exactly he meant. Would it not be possible to better them immediately?
That would mean another speech.
Question put: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time.”

MainHeading.P: Question again proposed: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time.”

Speaker.P: Last Thursday I was endeavouring to show the cost of the Seanad and Dáil at present as compared with the cost of Government before the setting up of the Free State. Another matter that weighs very heavily with Deputies in coming to a decision on this Bill is the fact that the mode of election to the Seanad has been changed by recent legislation. That convinces me that in the very near future the Seanad will be nothing more or less than a mere creature of the Dáil since the members of the Seanad will depend very much for their election to the Upper House upon the votes of members of the Dáil. Speaking generally on this Bill, I think that Deputies should keep before their minds the present economic position of the country, and they should do something in the way of reducing taxation. There has been a tendency during this debate more or less to raise a smoke screen around this Bill. References have been made to party funds and how these funds were acquired. I am not going to enter into that part of the discussion. The Bill is a very simple one and it requires a very straight and definite answer. I think the country expects that Deputies will vote for the measure. The country is looking forward to some tangible proof of the bona fides of Deputies when they state that taxation should be reduced. They have now an opportunity of reducing taxation. So far as I am concerned I have no hesitation in supporting this Bill. I believe it will be only the beginning of a policy of retrenchment which is so badly needed if this country is to get back to a prosperous condition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J.X. Murphy Mr. J.X. Murphy
Speaker.P: The only consideration that should make people decide whether they vote for or against this Bill is whether the State is justified in paying £360 a year to members of a merely criticising body. The Seanad, I admit, makes useful criticisms at times, but they have no executive powers. The Seanad cannot interfere with Money Bills, I understand. They have, theoretically, powers to hold up legislation for a short period of time; but really it amounts to this, that it is only a criticising body. Moreover, the members of the Seanad are more or less recruited from the leisured classes, and I doubt very much if a single member of the Seanad would resign if Deputy Thrift's Bill becomes law; in fact, my opinion—and I go further than Deputy Thrift—is that we would get a better body of critics if the members of the Seanad were not paid at all.

I agree with a great deal that Deputy Mathews said on Friday, but he was very inconsistent. He pleaded for economies. He said every mickle makes a muckle, and then he told us he was going to vote for this mickle. Apparently he is the inventor of a new theory, that half a loaf is worse than no bread. I hope, however, that when he comes to reconsider his decision he will change his mind about the way in which he will record his vote. I take it that as this is a Private Deputy's Bill the Government forces and the forces of the chief Opposition, Fianna Fáil, will not be marshalled and that everyone in the House will be free to give his opinion as to what he thinks is the proper course.

I shall not detain the House for many minutes, because there are really only two points that I want to make. The first point is in answer to the different criticisms that have been made on the Bill. I think that the one point really answers them all—whether it is a point like that of Deputy Law, who objects to our dealing with Senators and not dealing with ourselves, or a point made by a Deputy like Deputy Esmonde, who, with much misplaced ingenuity, tried to find abstruse reasons for the introduction of the Bill. In fact, every criticism that was made against the Bill is answered by one single point, and it is this. I want the House to consider the state of things in 1928, and the point I am making is so simple and clear that it can be argued almost with mathematical precision. In 1928 the Dáil and Seanad held that the circumstances and the expenses of Deputies and Senators were such that equal allowances were justified for both. In 1928 a Bill was passed into law which altered those circumstances in favour of Senators. It altered them in a very substantial way, because in future Senators are to be elected without the very large expense of election which then prevailed. Therefore, I contend it is perfectly clear that, if the circumstances were such as to justify equal allowances before 1928, in the autumn of 1928, when we altered those circumstances, we made the position such that the Senators cannot any longer justify equal allowances. On the Committee Stage of the Bill, if the Bill ever gets to a Committee Stage, it will be for the House to say whether the figure mentioned in the Bill is a proper figure to which the allowances of Senators should be reduced.

It seems to me to be perfectly and mathematically clear that if you make an alteration which alters the circumstances in favour of the Senators, that should be accompanied by a corresponding alteration in the allowances they are to receive. That is the reason why this Bill was introduced. This Bill was introduced immediately after the Bill had passed into law which made an alteration in the method of the election of Senators. Senators are no longer put to the expense of circularising a huge constituency; they are to be elected in the future simply by the votes of the Dáil and the Seanad, a method without expense to them.

MainHeading.P: The second point I wish to make is really a consequence of the first. So far as I am concerned, I would be prepared, on the Committee Stage, to accept an amendment that this reduction should take place for future Senators only. I wish to emphasise that what I have stated is the real reason for the introduction of the Bill. I am prepared, as I have said, to accept an amendment by which this will apply to future Senators only. That is simply stated on my own responsibility. I do not know whether the other Independent Deputies will take that view or not. I state that as my own view and I put it forward as a confirmation of the main argument which I have given as the reason for the Bill.

The Bill is capable of amendment on the Committee Stage in at least these two ways. As for the main principle of the Bill which we are discussing here on the Second Reading, it seems to me to be unanswerable that if before 1928 the circumstances justified equal allowances— and I have no doubt that the Dáil and Seanad were right in saying their circumstances justified equal allowances—then when you alter those circumstances in favour of Senators I submit that you should correspondingly diminish their allowances. I think the case for the Second Reading is unanswerable, and I ask the House to give the Bill a Second Reading.
Question put.
